blocks.content: Paper lanterns have a special place in my heart. They pull me into a world far from the England I grew up in: temples in the mountains, dragons on the eaves, stories I only knew from books. A lone lantern is a beacon on the path of adventure. A doorway framed by them is an invitation to explore deeper.

photos.caption: Triumphant lady after queuing an hour for this Hakone photo

blocks.content: Rocks and Zen gardens have the same pull as laterns. The gardens in Kyoto are restrained, delicate, and focused. Without distractions to hold onto or markers of time, it's easy to sit and lose yourself.

photos.caption: First one to arrive at Tenryu‑ji temple gardens
Leaving thoughts at the door before sitting at Daitoku‑ji temple

blocks.content: Tokyo always has a matsuri somewhere. One street is silent and deserted, then one block over a matsuri is flooding a street with so much life you’d assume it’s the centre of the world. In summer we went to the Yasukuni‑jinja matsuri. The entryway for half a kilometre was lined with thousands of large yellow lanterns, two imposing walls framing the shrine. Tokyo summer is punishingly hot and humid. Sweat ran down my neck and turned my t‑shirt light blue. The wet patches shimmered black under the yellow lantern light.

photos.caption: A cliff of lanterns at Yasukuni-jinja matsuri

blocks.content: Some temples were destinations; others were stumbled upon. Day trips were punctuated with fleeting glimpses of gates, roofs, and paper lanterns nestled among gardens and rocks.

photos.caption: Trail running with the Crossfit team

blocks.content: Not pictured: wooden steps where I perched on one foot to slip off shoes; devoted locals queuing for temple stamps; me, just as devoted to buying mochi and dango with crumpled yen from my back pocket.
